messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Real Writing
messages.msgSnippet: -=-Also true! Yesterday someone told me my advice was dangerous and the worst advice I ve ever seen on a homeschooling group‚Äô!-=- WHAT the heck‚Ä¶
messages.messageBody:
-=-Also true! Yesterday someone told me my 'advice' was 'dangerous' and 'the worst advice I've ever seen on a homeschooling group‚Äô!-=-


WHAT the heck‚Ä¶

I‚Äôve seen some god-awful advice on homeschooling groups. :-) And on unschooling groups. And when I‚Äôm an admin or the owner, I say ‚ÄúHey‚Ä¶ bad advice‚Äù (when I catch it, and if I don‚Äôt, someone else usually does).

-=-Said people weren't reading carefully though. And the second one clearly hadn't realised she was in an unschooling group, not a homeschooling group!-=-

The second one!? Two people didn‚Äôt appreciate you!? :-)
I hope their families are happy anyway, and that they remember your advice in case things happen to make them want to relax and risk some danger later on!

Dangerous‚Ä¶

I‚Äôve been told some crazy stuff. I‚Äôve been cursed. :-) It didn‚Äôt work. I wasn‚Äôt psychically crushed or anything.

I saved a a couple of them, and a couple shared by others, here: http://sandradodd.com/curses

Consider how powerful your writing must be, Jo, for someone to resort to that much to try to keep others from reading what you wrote. :-)
I consider, when people curse me, that they think I‚Äôm a potent and dangerous entitiy. And they only got that from reading what I wrote. Probably not very closely, or with much openness. :-) But still, somehow it scared them.

I‚Äôm not trying to be scary. I‚Äôm trying to pick ideas up and turn them over and see if they work, how they work, how they might be tweaked to work better.

Sandra

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Real Writing
messages.msgSnippet: ==‚ÄúPracticing‚Äù isn‚Äôt fair to what you‚Äôre doing. :-) Or maybe I want to remind people not to think of it as the kind of practicing piano teachers are
messages.messageBody:
==‚ÄúPracticing‚Äù isn‚Äôt fair to what you‚Äôre doing. :-) Or maybe I want to remind people not to think of it as the kind of practicing piano teachers are talking about.==

You are right - it's not really 'practicing'


==You‚Äôve been writing and becoming a better writer because you liked the writing and (maybe) the effect, or the ‚Äúrealness‚Äù of it.. ==

Exactly that!

==When you help unschooling parents, some of them might give you the equivalent of a D or an F. ==

Also true! Yesterday someone told me my 'advice' was 'dangerous' and 'the worst advice I've ever seen on a homeschooling group'!

Said people weren't reading carefully though. And the second one clearly hadn't realised she was in an unschooling group, not a homeschooling group!

Jo



From: AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com <AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com> on behalf of Sandra Dodd Sandra@... [AlwaysLearning] <AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: 19 August 2018 15:50
To: Always Learning
Subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Real Writing
 
 

Jo wrote:

-=-I won the prize - I told my husband, and he said 'Well, no wonder yours won, you spend most of the day writing to Moms on Facebook!'
-=-I hadn't, until then, ever really thought that responding on unschooling groups was practicing my writing skills, but I guess it is üòä-=-

‚ÄúPracticing‚Äù isn‚Äôt fair to what you‚Äôre doing. :-) Or maybe I want to remind people not to think of it as the kind of practicing piano teachers are talking about.

You‚Äôve been writing and becoming a better writer because you liked the writing and (maybe) the effect, or the ‚Äúrealness‚Äù of it.. When writing has an audience, or can have an effect, that‚Äôs way better feedback than a writing teacher writing ‚ÄúGood job! A‚Äù

I‚Äôve competed with other monkeys for the prize of a teacher writing ‚ÄúA‚Äù on a paper and handing it back. Sometimes I was learning, and sometimes I was learning that some teachers only want one kind of thing, and that‚Äôs the new trick to perform. Lots and lots of work goes into those contests to avoid having a teacher write a ‚ÄúB‚Äù of a ‚ÄúC‚Äù (or worse).

Most of that is ‚Äúpractice writing.‚Äù

When you help unschooling parents, some of them might give you the equivalent of a D or an F. Some of them give me the equivalent of SCREW YOU and walking out and telling other people I‚Äôm horrible. Some of those didn‚Äôt want to unschool anyway. Some of those come back later, because the agitation caused them to obsess about what ‚Äúdumb‚Äù things they had read, or had caused them to stuff it all down, but life caused it to pop back up, when their kids were unhappy after a while.

So immediate feedback is the only reward in school. The writing has a deadline. The grades have a deadline. End of semester, all done.

Writing for unschoolers is different.

There are some people who haven‚Äôt been born yet who will, someday, read things Jo Isaac wrote, and other people here. It might be hard for them to find it, or it might not be. But good ideas, written well, can outlive the writers.

Sandra

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Real Writing
messages.msgSnippet: Jo wrote: -=-I won the prize - I told my husband, and he said Well, no wonder yours won, you spend most of the day writing to Moms on Facebook! -=-I hadn t,

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Real Writing
messages.msgSnippet: A couple of weeks ago, I did a First Aid course. At the end, the instructor said if we went online and wrote a Google review, we were in the running for a $50
messages.messageBody:
A couple of weeks ago, I did a First Aid course. At the end, the instructor said if we went online and wrote a Google review, we were in the running for a $50 shopping voucher - for whoever wrote the weeks best review.

So, ever the bargain hunter, I came home and wrote a review for them. 

I won the prize - I told my husband, and he said 'Well, no wonder yours won, you spend most of the day writing to Moms on Facebook!'

I hadn't, until then, ever really thought that responding on unschooling groups was practicing my writing skills, but I guess it is üòä

Jo




From: AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com <AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com> on behalf of Sandra Dodd Sandra@... [AlwaysLearning] <AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: 19 August 2018 07:32
To: Always Learning
Subject: [AlwaysLearning] Real Writing
 
 

It will take a few posts, over a few days, or longer, for me to bring some things I wanted to present to help readers think about ‚Äúreal writing.‚Äù

Lisa Celedon wrote this (in a longer post elsehwere):
____________
Thanks for all the years of help and encouragement and good, thought-provoking discussion. The level of critical analysis in this discussion and always learning is more sophisticated, clear, and useful than the critical analysis in my graduate level literature classes. :) They've really helped me be a better parent and person.
____________

Writing and discussions in school are a sort of test, and a competition. Which student will say the cleverest thing? Which essay or report will be the clearest, maybe say something new and different, and not have too many errors of mechanics or technicalities? But the professor‚Äôs probably not wanting to learn anything new, and the students are trying to get the highest scores with the least effort.

Meanwhile, among the mostly-unemployed moms discussiing parenting and unschooling over here, the writing is honest, heartfelt, offered up in hopes that it will help unseen, uncounted others. Or hoping it might help one other, who hasn‚Äôt even joined the group yet, who will come across it later, someday.

‚ÄúReal,‚Äù for me, means real-life. Writing that‚Äôs honest and practical and that will be received by some people who will be thinking as they read it of whether and how they could apply the ideas in their own real lives, that very day, or week, or season. Or someday. Or comparing it to what they know and letting it strengthen their own existing ideas and practices.

More to come from me later, but if others here have already brought so many good examples that mine are superfluous, that would be just fine. :-)

Sandra

messages.subject: Real Writing
messages.msgSnippet: My e-mail isn t going out right for some reason, and as I was starting to respond to an e-mail (from someone on this list), I realized I could write and write
messages.messageBody:
My e-mail isn't going out right for some reason, and as I was starting to respond to an e-mail (from someone on this list), I realized I could write and write and she wouldn't get a response. Then I thought it was useful to others, too, so here it is:

___________________

-=-I've always thought of myself as a lousy writer --funny that that is changing too in this path toward radical unschooling, as my idea of myself is becoming less and less negative) -=-

You could write about that, at the beginning of your presentation.

I don't think it's that your thoughts about yourself made you think the same old writing was better. I think you've been writing more, and for a real audience, about things that were important to you and that they actually needed to know, and wanted to read. That is real writing, in the real world. Because of that your writing probably IS better.

All the writing students do for teachers is pretend, practice writing. Every report written in school is a practice report, not a real report. Kids are writing about something that's already known, for people who don't really want to know. A real report is like this:
http://sandradodd.blogspot.co.uk/2012/06/windsor-ox-roast.html

Even if just one person reads it who thinks it's interesting, I've provided information that they couldn't get another way. I was an eye witness. And I link to other reports from other years.

This is a real report, because I was reporting what I saw and what I knew about what I saw:
http://sandradodd.blogspot.co.uk/2012/06/beacon-lit-in-staines.html

If you write about what you have done at your house, and what you thought about it, that's reporting about family relationships, child development, the results of different methods and ideas put into practice.

If you share ideas on Always Learning, that's analysis and collaboration and the clarification of other people's ideas. Sometimes that's rephrasing and sometimes that's finding the seed of truth in a jumble of data. Sometimes it's sorting emotion from evidence.

Writing to real people for real purposes improves writing in real ways.

Sandra
